lines.text: I want you to give yourself up.
So I can live a long and fruitful life?
Oh, we can work something out.

[laughs]
Jesus, Frank don't fucking lie to me. I have a rendezvous with death, and so does the President, and so do you Frank if you get too close to me.
You have a rendezvous with my ass, motherfucker!
Was that you shooting?
Yes.
That's a cool gun you got there. Could I see it?
[Leary gives him the gun]
Shit, that's light! What's it made of?
Composite. Like plastic.
Mind if I give it a little dance?
[Leary shrugs. The hunter shoots a duck]
That is great! That is really really great! You wouldn't want to sell it would you?
No, I need it.
For what?
To assassinate the president.
[Hunters laugh]
Now what do you want to do that for, mister?
Why'd you kill that bird, asshole?
[proceeds to nonchalantly kill both of the hunters with his gun]
I've never worked with a female agent before. How many are there?
About 125.
Mm. Pure window dressing.
Excuse me?
Window dressing. About 125 out of a little over 2,000. They have you all around so that the President can look good to his feminist voters.
Do you make an effort to be obnoxious, or is it a gift?
it'd take an anti-tank missile to put a dent in that damn thing. There we are, out for show, trying to make the President look more presidential.
[last lines]
I'll bet you that brown pigeon down there flies off before the white one.
How do you know?
I know things about pigeons, Lilly.
The irony is so thick you could choke on it.
There's no fuckin' irony, Mitch.
Think, Frank. Think. The same government that trained me to kill trained you to protect. Yet now you want to kill me while up on that roof I protected you. They're gonna write books about us, Frank.
I don't know, maybe I'm... maybe I'm just wrong for the job.
You're a good man, Al. You'll make a good agent.
How do you know? This is the longest conversation we've ever had.
I know things about people.
What makes you think he'll call again?
Oh, he'll call again. He's got, uh, "panache."
Panache?
Yeah, it means flamboyance.
Mm, I know what it means.
Really? I had to look it up.
[Lilly's wearing an evening dress]
What are you looking at?
I was just wondering where you hide your firearm. Don't tell me, let me guess.
So you had an affair with an agent, and it came out badly.
He wasn't an agent.
But he left you because you wouldn't quit your job. You were broken-hearted.
I left him, Frank, because I wouldn't quit my job for him. And it did break my heart.
You vowed never again to ever let a man come between you and your career.
No...
Except... now you're in love with me, and it screws your little head up.
Frank, blow your nose. Here.
Sorry. What were to happen if I, uh, gave up my job for you?
Why would you do that?
Well, maybe I vowed to never again let my career come between me and a woman.

[Leary is hanging from an elevator alongside a hotel building. Horrigan offers his hand to him]
Take my hand. If you don't, you'll die.

[smiling]
Do you want to save me, Frank?
To be frank and honest with you, no. But it's my job.
I know who you are - Leary.
I'm glad, Frank. Friends should be able to call each other by name.
We're not friends.
Sure we are.
I've seen what you do to friends.
What's that supposed to mean?
You slit your friend's throat.
You talked to Coppinger, Frank?
Yeah, that's right.
Did you delouse? The man's a professional liar.
I saw the photos.
No, you saw what he wanted you to see, Frank.
I saw a picture of, uh, your friend lying on the floor with his throat cut.
they sent my best friend - my comrade in arms - to my home to kill me!
[Frank watches Lilly leave from the Lincoln Memorial]
If she looks back, it means she's interested. Come on, give me a look back now. Just give me that smug expression and be on your way.
[Lilly looks back]
Well, Abe? Damn... wish I could have been there for you, pal.
The President was humiliated.
He's alive, isn't he?
Yeah, well, we're here to safeguard his dignity as well.
I'm not paid for that.
What about the time Kennedy's girlfriend was caught in the White House and you said she was with you?
Don't you go believing every rumor someone tells you.
Frank, Wilder told me the whole story. About how you were suspended a month without pay. I'd say that was safeguarding his dignity.
That was different. *He* was different.
Maybe you were different.
I was different. The whole damn country was different. Everything would be different right now too if I'd been half as a paranoid as I am today. Fuck.
Frank, The President sent his limo for you.
Well, that's the least he could do.
Good, I love public transportation.
How's the First Lady? She ask about me?
Have you gotten to know them yet?
Well, I normally prefer not to get to know the people I'm protecting.
Oh, yeah? Why's that?
Well, you never know. You might decide they're not worth taking a bullet for.
Watching the President, I - I couldn't help wondering why a man like you would risk his life to save a man like that. You have such a strange job - I can't decide if it's heroic or absurd.
Now, why would a man like you want to risk his life to kill a man like that?
Don't you have a psychological profile on me yet?
I don't put a lot of stock in them.
Nor do I. A man's actions don't equal the sum of his psychological parts. Doesn't work that way.
Just how does it work?

It doesn't work, Frank. God doesn't punish the wicked and reward the righteous. Everyone dies. Some die because they deserve to; others die simply because they come from Minneapolis. It's random and it's meaningless.
Well, if none of this means anything... why kill the President?
To punctuate the dreariness.
There's no cause left worth fighting for, Frank. All we have is the game. I'm on offense, you're on defense.
Well, when do we start playing the game?
The clock's ticking, Frank.
You okay?
No, I'm not okay. I'm sick, I'm tired, and I'm armed too, so be careful.
You're also maybe a genius.
Huh - not to be recognized in this lifetime.
What do you know about the guy?
Well, d'you see this wheelchair? Mitch bought it for me. Cost over $1,000. See this?
[holds up gun]
Whoa, whoa, take it easy now...
This is in case he ever comes back.
What to do you see when you're in the dark, and the demons come?
I see you, Frank. I see you standing over the grave of another dead president.
That's not going to happen. I'm onto you.
Fuck you Frank. I am willing to trade my life for his. I am smart, and I am willing, and that is all it takes. That president is coming home from California in a fucking box.
Where in California?
Uh, the address? Come on, Frank. I'll keep you in the game, but I'm not going to throw it for you.
You're looking at a living legend, Lilly. The only active agent who ever lost a president.
Frank, you of all people, I want you to understand because we both USED to think this country was a very special place...
You don't know what I used to think!
Oh, but you know about me? Do you have any idea what I've done for God and country? Some pretty FUCKING HORRIBLE things! I don't even remember who I was before they sunk their claws into me!
They made you into a real monster, right?
That's right and now they want to destroy me because we can't have monsters roaming the quiet countryside, now can we?

[Horrigan and Leary are in a glass elevator. Sharpshooters are in place to take out Leary but can't see the target because the lights in the elevator are out. Horrigan is on the floor while Leary is standing over him and pointing a gun at him. Unbeknownst to Leary, Horrigan has a microphone concealed in his hand and is transmitting]
Go ahead and shoot, dammit.
They can't see inside. If they fire, you'll be hit.
I want you to thank me first, Frank.
Shut up and shoot.
All right, Frank.
All right, Frank.
Shooters, stand by to fire. Wait for my command.

[Cocks the gun]
Sleep well, my friend.
aim high.
What?
Aim high.
Now!

[Sees the microphone and realizes Horrigan has been talking to Raines]
You bastard!
Fire.
[Glass is shattered by gunfire. Leary is forced to duck, giving Horrigan an opportunity to grapple with him]
[Leary makes the first of a series of taunting phone calls]
McCrawley?
Why not call me Booth?
Why not Oswald?
Because Booth had flair, panache - a leap to the stage after he shot Lincoln.
What's kept you in the game all these years?
Why don't we get together and have a drink? We could talk about that.
Oh, I'd love to, but I think the less you know about me the better.
Oh, why?
Because I'm planning to kill the President.
Oh, now you shouldn't have gone and said that. It's a federal offense to threaten the President. You could go to jail, even if you don't mean it.
I mean it all right. John F. Kennedy said all someone needs is a willingness to trade his life for the President's, right?
That's right.
I'm willing.
The number of that San Diego office?
Uh, 619-UKELELE.
Ukulele?
That's how I remember it, you know, 7 numbers, 7 letters? You just push U-K-E-L-E-L-E. Easy.
Uh, wait a minute, isn't "ukulele" spelled U-K-U-?
I dunno... but the phone number's U-K-E-L-E-L-E.

[speaking to Horrigan on the phone]
Do you know how easily I could kill you, Frank? Do you know how many times I watched you go in and out of that apartment? You are still alive because I have allowed you to live so you show me some GODDAMN RESPECT!
[slams phone down]
[On the phone]
Trying to trace me, Frank?
Heh, now why didn't I think of that?
You did, or you're not the adversary I'd hoped for.
[in the elevator]
Ok, now what?
Do you believe in the nobility of suicide?
No. But if you wanna blow your goddamn head off, go ahead, be my guest.
Nicely put, Frank, but I don't want to leave this miserable world alone.
Well, the secretaries get prettier and prettier.
And the field agents get older and older.
Lilly's an agent, Frank.
I knew that. I just wanted to see if she had a sense of humor.
Do you have what it takes to take a bullet, or is life too precious?
Well I'll be thinkin' about that when I'm pissin' on your grave.
[Assassination attempt botched, Leary takes Horrigan hostage onto a hotel elevator]

[removing facial disguise]
So, you have the guts, Frank. You took the bullet.

[holding his chest]
I think you broke my damn ribs.
Sorry, I wasn't aiming at you.
I heard you and Nixon didn't get along.

Now, that's not true. His chief of staff, though, that was a different story. I remember one time, he wanted me to go out and get rid of some anti-war protestors. I said no, talking about the Bill of Rights and so on. And he says, "look, when I'm talking to you, I am the President." I said, "The President? That's funny, you look more like a sack of shit in a cheap suit to me, sir!"

[laughs]
Well, I like the "sir." It's a classy touch.
I thought so.

[after someone called the paramedics]
Okay, who's the joker?
It may not have been a joke, you were looking kind of peaked out there.
Well, when I find out who it was, I'm gonna pay him back in spades.
What makes you think it was a *him*?
[walks away]

You know, for years now I've listened to all these idiots on barstools, with their pet theories on Dallas. How it was the Cubans, or the CIA, or the white supremacists, or the Mob. Whether there was one weapon, or whether there was five. None of that's meant too much to me. But Leary... he questioned whether I had the guts to take that fatal bullet. God, that was a beautiful day. The sun was out, been raining all morning, the air was... First shot sounded like a firecracker. I looked over, I saw him, I could tell he was hit. I don't know why I didn't react. I should have reacted. I should have been running flat-out. I just couldn't believe it. If only I'd reacted, I could have taken that shot. And that would have been alright with me.
[Leary's final words on Frank's answering machine]

Hello, Frank. By the time you hear this, it'll be over. The President is most likely dead, and so am I. I wonder, Frank, did you kill me? Who won our game? Not that it really matters, for among friends like you and me, it's not whether you win or lose but how you play the game, and now the game is done and it's time to get on with your life. But I worry, Frank, that you have no life to get on with. You're a good man, and good men like you and me are destined to walk a lonely road. Goodbye, and good luck.

What did happen to you that day? Only one agent reacted to the gunfire, and you were closer to Kennedy than he was. You must have looked up at the window of the Texas Book Depository, but you didn't react. Late at night, when the demons come, do you see the rifle coming out of that window, or do you see Kennedy's head being blown apart? If you'd reacted to that first shot, could you have gotten there in time to stop the big bullet? And if you had - that could've been your head being blown apart. Do you wish you'd succeeded, Frank? Or is life too precious?
Leary is what we nowadays call a wet boy.
What's a wet boy, Frank?
Leary's an assassin.
Oh, Jesus.
In Leary's case, that's putting it too gently. He's more like a predator.
What do you think I ought to do here, Frank?
Make sure the body doesn't wash up on shore.
I want you to pop him for me, ok? See I think maybe you're with him.
Look, you came to me remember?
So pop him, show me I'm an asshole.
I'm just a business man.
So pop him. And let's do some business.

[Frank is arguing with the Chief of Staff]
This a just a big joke to you, Horrigan?
lines.character: White House Chief of Staff Harry Sargent

lines.text: No, YOU'RE a joke to me, Harry! You have no idea what we do around here!
That's enough, Horrigan!
By God, if you call me Harry once more, you'll be busting counterfeiters in Alaska!
lines.character: White House Chief of Staff Harry Sargent

lines.text: Well, time flies when you're being annoyed.
[second phone call]
I was worried about you with the motorcade today. You looked like you were going to faint. You really should get into shape for that type of job.
[about 15 minutes later into the film when the Secret Service is looking through the park]

[sees Frank exhuasted through binocoluars and mutters]
I told you to get into shape.

[Horrigan is hanging from a roof]
Take my hand, Frank. Take it, if you don't you'll die.

[Horrigan does and then pulls his gun out]
You're gonna shoot me Frank after I saved your life? The only way to save the president is to shoot me. Are you willing to trade your life for his or is life too precious?
[after saving the president]
Why are you retiring from the Secret Service?
Well, because I hate desk work and I'm too old to go running along the limousines, and thanks to you people plastering my picture up everywhere I'm no good for undercover work.
You shouldn't have been from Minneapolis.
If she looks back, that means she's interested. Come on now give me a little look, a little glance back. Give me a small look and be on your way!
The election's in three weeks. You're asking me to commit political suicide.
lines.character: White House Chief of Staff Harry Sargent

lines.text: I'm asking you to stay out of California.
If this guy's so smart, he's not gonna come out and tell you where he's gonna make an attempt.
lines.character: White House Chief of Staff Harry Sargent

lines.text: I don't think he'd lie to me.
Well, isn't that sweet? You've become that close, have you? Look, people, California is the key to the whole damn race. We've narrowed the gap to five points. We can't let up now.
lines.character: White House Chief of Staff Harry Sargent

lines.text: Then we'll have to change our procedures. Move him around in unmarked cars. Uh... frisk everyone within fifty yards.
Frisk people going into $10,000 a plate dinners? You're overreacting again, Horrigan.
lines.character: White House Chief of Staff Harry Sargent

lines.text: If I don't overreact, the president's dead.
[first lines]

[running late]
Oh, my God. Oh, my God. Oh, Frank, thank God. Thank God. I'm dead. I'm dead. I'm dead. I'm dead.

[Spots Leary at the fundraiser about to shoot the president]
GUN!
Leary, don't FUCKING move!
The world can be a cruel place to an honest man, Frank.
